page.title: 14LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: There is no definite village in Bishop Thornton, but it contains scattered hamlets and farmhouses. The boundaries of the parish are the streams and faults in the land. Bishop Thornton was mentioned in the Domesday Book as "TORENTUME", which means "Farmstead surrounded by thorns." It had the pre-fix "Bishop" because the land was owned by the Archbishop of York and the first record we have is in 1030. "Tun" is the commonest English settlement name. Other hamlets are Dole Bank, which was a Nunnery, Hardgate, Shaw Mills, ( so called because Robert Shaw opened a corn mill there in the 16th Century. Over the years it has been used for flax, cotton, hemp, silk and suede finishing). Raventoft's and Gillmoor which belonged to Fountains Abbey and was farmed by the monks.
